# About
**Lab:** Working with RDDs
**Objective:** Use the Spark shell to work with RDDs
**File locations:**
    /home/devuser/data/telco/frostroad.txt
    /home/devuser/data/telco/makes1.txt
    /home/devuser/data/telco/makes2.txt
    
**Successful outcome:** 
**Before you begin:** 
**Related lessons:** 

---

msg.data:
About

Lab: Working with RDDs
Objective: Use the Spark shell to work with RDDs
File locations:

$DEVDATA/frostroad.txt
$DEVDATA/makes1.txt
$DEVDATA/makes2.txt

Successful outcome:
Before you begin:
Related lessons:

Setup

Important: This exercise depends on ***Insert previous exercise title here (with link?)*** . If you did not complete that exercise, run the course catch-up script and advance to the current exercise:

$ $DEVSH/scripts/catchup.sh
Lab

paragraphs.text:
%md
### Review the API Documentation for RDD Operations

msg.data: Review the API Documentation for RDD Operations

paragraphs.title: 1 - Review the API documentation for the RDD class
paragraphs.text:
%md
Review the API docs for the RDD class (which is in the Python module `pyspark`). Take note of the various available operations.

msg.data:
Review the API docs for the RDD class (which is in the Python module pyspark,
and the Scala package org.apache.spark.rdd). Take note of the various
available operations.

paragraphs.text:
%md
### Read and Display Data from a Text File

msg.data: Read and Display Data from a Text File

paragraphs.title: 2 - Review the text file that will be the source of data
paragraphs.text:
%md
Review the simple text file you will be using by viewing (without editing) the file in a separate window (not the Spark shell). The file is located at `/home/devuser/data/telco/frostroad.txt`.

msg.data:
Review the simple text file you will be using by viewing (without editing) the
file in a separate window (not the Spark shell). The file is located at $DEVDATA/frostroad.txt.

paragraphs.title: 3 - Upload the text file to HDFS
paragraphs.text:
%md
In a terminal window on your remote desktop, upload the text file to HDFS directory `/user/zeppelin/`.

msg.data:
In a terminal window on your remote desktop, upload the text file to HDFS
directory /devsh_loudacre.

$ hdfs dfs -put $DEVDATA/frostroad.txt /devsh_loudacre/

paragraphs.title: 4 - Define an RDD based on the source data
paragraphs.text:
%md
In the Spark shell, define an RDD based on the `frostroad.txt` text file.

msg.data: In the Spark shell, define an RDD based on the frostroad.txt text file.

paragraphs.title: 5 - Review the available transformations and actions for an RDD
paragraphs.text:
%md
Using command completion, you can see all the available transformations and actions you can perform on an RDD. Type `myRDD.` and then the `TAB` key.

msg.data:
Using command completion, you can see all the available transformations and
actions you can perform on an RDD. Type myRDD. and then the TAB key.

paragraphs.title: 6 - Perform an action on the RDD to materialize it in Spark
paragraphs.text:
%md
Spark has not yet read the file. It will not do so until you perform an action on the RDD. Try counting the number of elements in the RDD using the `count` action:

msg.data:
Spark has not yet read the file. It will not do so until you perform an action on the
RDD. Try counting the number of elements in the RDD using the count action:

paragraphs.text:
%md
The `count` operation causes the RDD to be materialized (created and populated).
The number of lines (23) should be returned.

msg.data:
The count operation causes the RDD to be materialized (created and populated).
The number of lines (23) should be displayed, for example:

    Out[2]: 23

paragraphs.title: 7 - Use the collect operation to return all data
paragraphs.text:
%md
Call the `collect` operation to return all data in the RDD to the Spark driver. Take note of the type of the return value; it will be a list of strings.

**Note:** `collect` returns the entire set of data. This is convenient for very small RDDs like this one, but be careful using `collect` for more typical large sets of data.

msg.data:
Call the collect operation to return all data in the RDD to the Spark driver. Take
note of the type of the return value; in Python will be a list of strings, and in Scala it
will be an array of strings.

Note: collect returns the entire set of data. This is convenient for very small
RDDs like this one, but be careful using collect for more typical large sets of data.

paragraphs.title: 8 - Display the collected data
paragraphs.text:
%md
Display the contents of the collected data by looping through the collection.

msg.data: Display the contents of the collected data by looping through the collection.
Transform Data in an RDD

paragraphs.title: 9 - Review the data files you will be using in this exercise
paragraphs.text:
%md
In this exercise, you will load two text files containing the names of various cell phone makes, and append one to the other. Review the two text files you will be using by viewing (without editing) the file in a separate window. The files are `makes1.txt` and `makes2.txt` in the `/home/devuser/data/telco/` directory.

msg.data:
In this exercise, you will load two text files containing the names of various cell
phone makes, and append one to the other. Review the two text files you will be
using by viewing (without editing) the file in a separate window. The files are
makes1.txt and makes2.txt in the $DEVDATA directory.

paragraphs.title: 10 - Upload the data files to HDFS
paragraphs.text:
%md
Upload the two text files to HDFS directory `/user/zeppelin/`.

msg.data:
Upload the two text files to HDFS directory /devsh_loudacre.

$ hdfs dfs -put $DEVDATA/makes*.txt /devsh_loudacre/

paragraphs.title: 11 - Create an RDD based on makes1.txt
paragraphs.text:
%md
In Spark, create an RDD called `makes1RDD` based on the `/user/zeppelin/makes1.txt` file.

msg.data: In Spark, create an RDD called makes1RDD based on the /devsh_loudacre/makes1.txt file.

paragraphs.title: 12 - Display the contents from makes1 using collect
paragraphs.text:
%md
Display the contents of the `makes1RDD` data using `collect` and then looping through the returned colleciton.

msg.data: Display the contents of the makes1RDD data using collect and then looping through the returned colleciton.

paragraphs.title: 13 - Create and display an RDD based on makes2.txt
paragraphs.text:
%md
Repeat the previous steps to create and display an RDD called `makes2RDD` based on the second file, `/user/zeppelin/makes2.txt`.

msg.data:
Repeat the previous steps to create and display an RDD called makes2RDD based
on the second file, /devsh_loudacre/makes2.txt.

paragraphs.title: 14 - Create a new RDD using the union transformation
paragraphs.text:
%md
Create a new RDD by appending the second RDD to the first using the `union` transformation.

msg.data: Create a new RDD by appending the second RDD to the first using the union transformation.

paragraphs.title: 15 - Collect and display the combined RDD
paragraphs.text:
%md
Collect and display the contents of the new `allMakesRDD` RDD.

msg.data: Collect and display the contents of the new allMakesRDD RDD.

paragraphs.title: 16 - Remove duplicates from the combined RDD
paragraphs.text:
%md
Use the `distinct` transformation to remove duplicates from `allMakesRDD`. Collect and display the contents to confirm that duplicate elements were removed.

msg.data:
Use the distinct transformation to remove duplicates from allMakesRDD.
Collect and display the contents to confirm that duplicate elements were removed.

paragraphs.title: 17 - Experiment with other transformations from the RDD API
paragraphs.text:
%md
*Optional:* Try performing different transformations on the RDDs you created above, such as `intersection`, `subtract`, or `zip`. See the RDD API documentation for details.

msg.data:
Optional: Try performing different transformations on the RDDs you created above,
such as intersection, subtract, or zip. See the RDD API documentation for
details.

Result

You have now:
Solution

paragraphs.title: 6 - Perform an action on the RDD to materialize it in Spark
7 - Use the collect operation to return all data
8 - Display the collected data

msg.data:
Two roads diverged in a yellow wood,
And sorry I could not travel both
And be one traveler, long I stood
And looked down one as far as I could
To where it bent in the undergrowth;

Then took the other, as just as fair,
And having perhaps the better claim,
Because it was grassy and wanted wear;
Though as for that the passing there
Had worn them really about the same,

And both that morning equally lay
In leaves no step had trodden black.
Oh, I kept the first for another day!
Yet knowing how way leads on to way,
I doubted if I should ever come back.

I shall be telling this with a sigh
Somewhere ages and ages hence:
Two roads diverged in a wood, and I--
I took the one less traveled by,
And that has made all the difference.
Transform Data in an RDD

paragraphs.text:
%md
We hope you've enjoyed this lab. Below are additional resources that you should find useful:

1. [Hortonworks Apache Spark Tutorials](http://hortonworks.com/tutorials/#tuts-developers) are your natural next step where you can explore Spark in more depth.
2. [Hortonworks Community Connection (HCC)](https://community.hortonworks.com/spaces/85/data-science.html?type=question) is a great resource for questions and answers on Spark, Data Analytics/Science, and many more Big Data topics.
3. [Hortonworks Apache Spark Docs](https://docs.hortonworks.com/HDPDocuments/HDP3/HDP-3.0.1/spark-overview/content/analyzing_data_with_apache_spark.html) - official Spark documentation.
4. [Hortonworks Apache Zeppelin Docs](https://docs.hortonworks.com/HDPDocuments/HDP3/HDP-3.0.1/zeppelin-overview/content/overview.html) - official Zeppelin documentation.

msg.data:
We hope you've enjoyed this lab. Below are additional resources that you should find useful:

  1. Hortonworks Apache Spark Tutorials are your natural next step where you can explore Spark in more depth.
  2. Hortonworks Community Connection (HCC) is a great resource for questions and answers on Spark, Data Analytics/Science, and many more Big Data topics.
  3. Hortonworks Apache Spark Docs - official Spark documentation.
  4. Hortonworks Apache Zeppelin Docs - official Zeppelin documentation.
